Ken,

I think that you're right on that. As we showed in the paper, without=

evolution social learning fails pretty pathetically. Evolution therefore i=
s
adding the potential for novel behaviors to emerge. I suppose you could
v=
iew it as balancing the explore vs. exploit problem, where evolution is
han=
dling exploration and social learning is exploiting strong behaviors.

When=
 we start to think about novelty search in that case, it's less clear
wheth=
er it would fit in. Novelty is basically trying to cover the behavior
space=
 as thoroughly as possible, where as social learning is trying to
merge alr=
eady discovered behaviors. On the surface they seem to be opposing
forces, =
but I think it could work if we define the behavior space for
novelty searc=
h differently than for the acceptability function. Since
acceptability func=
tions operate at a lower level (collections of actions)
than most of the no=
velty search work I've seen, this seems reasonable.

For example, the maze =
task measured novelty as the final location of the
agent. You could define =
an acceptability function that only accepts moving
closer to the flag than =
has ever been seen. In this case, you would have
some initial exploitation =
by observing movement to the dead-end, but after
that the agents would make=
 no more progress and would not learn, enabling
novelty search to take over=
 and find the goal again. In less
discontinuously deceptive tasks, the comb=
ination of the two may work out
really well.

Sincerely,
Wesley
